4. Order of operations

BOEDMAS: integers and exponents

Without using your calculator, evaluate the following expression:

(−1)6×3(−1)6×3

Note: If you use your calculator, you will not learn how to use BOEDMAS.

Answer: (−1)6×3(−1)6×3 =
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The ordering of BOEDMAS is the key here - this expression has an exponent, so that needs to be done first.

STEP: Remember what BOEDMAS tells us
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Whenever we evaluate an expression, we must follow the order of operations, BOEDMAS. Here is what BOEDMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later.
  2. "E" ⟶⟶ do any exponents; exponents always come before multiplication and division!
  3. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

So it is helpful to think of the order of operations as four steps: BO-E-DM-AS.

STEP: Start with the exponent
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

In this question, there are two operations: multiplication and an exponent. BOEDMAS tells us to start with the exponent. Since the base is -1, and the exponent is even, evaluating the exponent will give us 1.

Then using this result, we need to do the multiplication. It is useful to organise our work into a nice funnel shape, as shown below, to keep track of all of our steps.

Therefore the final answer is 3.

Submit your answer as:

BODMAS: the order of operations including brackets

Complete this question without using a calculator. You should write down your working first, and then type in your final answer.

Find the value of this expression:

2×(11−3)2×(11−3).

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: 2×(11−3)2×(11−3). This expression includes subtraction and multiplication, but it also includes brackets! We always do the operations inside brackets before operations outside of the brackets! In this case that means we must start with subtraction, and the multiplication must wait.

Following BO-DM-AS, multiplication and division always come before addition and subtraction!

The calculation in brackets is highlighted in blue in the work below. After we finish the calculations in the brackets, we can leave the brackets off!

It is important for you to organise your working like the example above. Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. Keeping your work organised like this will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 1616.

BOEDMAS: integers and brackets

Answer the following two questions about this expression: −6×[(−1)+2]−6×[(−1)+2]

  1. Without using your calculator, Find the value of the expression above.

    −6×[(−1)+2]−6×[(−1)+2]

    Note: If you use your calculator, you will not learn how to use BOEDMAS.

    Answer: −6×[(−1)+2]−6×[(−1)+2] =
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    The first letter in BOEDMAS is "B", so you should start with the brackets before you evaluate the rest of the expression. In this question, the brackets that you need to look at are the square ones, since there are no operations inside the round brackets.

    STEP: Start with the brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    In this question, we need to start at the beginning of BOEDMAS with "B" for brackets. Here, that means starting inside the square brackets, since there are no operations inside the round ones.

    Inside the brackets, we are doing addition. Specifically, we must evaluate −1+2−1+2. Since we are adding, and one of the numbers is negative and one is positive, the value inside the brackets will be 1.

    STEP: Do the operation outside the brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Now that we have done everything inside the brackets, we can do the calculation outside them.

    Since we are doing multiplication, where the number outside the brackets is negative, the final solution will be -6.

    It is useful to organise our work in a nice funnel shape, to keep track of our steps as we do them.

    So the final answer is -6.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Do the brackets in the expression affect the final value of the expression? In other words, if we take away the brackets, will the answer change or not?

    Answer:

    Did the brackets affect the final answer?

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Imagine there are no brackets in the expression. If you evaluate this, will the final answer be the same?

    STEP: Evaluate the expression without any brackets
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Imagine there are no brackets in the expression, and instead it looks like:

    −6×(−1)+2−6×(−1)+2

    Will we still work out the answer in the same order that we did in Question 1?

    Since the operations in the expression are addition and multiplication, and the addition was inside the brackets and was done first in Question 1, the order will change.

    BOEDMAS tells us that multiplication and division must happen before addition and subtraction. This is not what we did when the brackets were there. For the original expression, we did the addition, and then the multiplication. Without the brackets, we did the multiplication, and then the addition.

    The calculations below show that the answer is not the same as what we had in Question 1.

    The brackets will change the final value of the expression. Therefore, the answer is Yes.

    Submit your answer as:

BODMAS: the order of operations

Complete this question without using a calculator. You should write down your working first, and then type in your final answer.

Evaluate the following expression:

6×7−7×66×7−7×6.

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
Follow BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in the expression, so start by looking for multiplication and/or division: remember that you must do them left to right. After you do 'DM', move to addition and/or subtraction; these also must be done from left to right.
STEP: <no title>
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

You must follow BO-DM-AS to evaluate the expression to get the answer. This expression does not have any brackets, so you can jump past 'BO' to the 'DM' step... This expression includes three operations: multiplication, subtraction and a second multiplication: 6×7−7×66×7−7×6.

Which operation is the first one to do? Of all the operations in the expression, the first one must be multiplication. To decide this, ignore any addition or subtraction for now (because 'DM' comes before 'AS'!), and then go from left to right looking for multiplication or division. The first calculation to do is at the front of the expression: 6×76×7. In fact, you must do multiplication twice. Remember that for these two calculation you should do the one on the left first!

Subtraction will be the last operation which you do.

The correct steps are shown here, with each calculation highlighted with the blue line and arrow. Your working should also be arranged like this, in the shape of a funnel where the numbers simply 'drop' down as you go.

The correct final answer is 00.

Critical Thinking: where do the brackets belong?

The equation shown here is missing brackets, and so it is false. Correct the equation by adding one pair of brackets in the correct places. You may use a calculator to help yourself solve this question.

8÷10+5−7=18÷10+5−7=1.

INSTRUCTIONS:
  1. Retype the entire equation in the answer box, putting brackets in the correct places.
  2. If needed, use "*" for multiplication and "/" for division.
Answer: The correct equation is: .
one-of
type(equation.strict)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Whatever you try with the expression, you must follow BO-DM-AS. So put some brackets around some of the numbers and see what happens - if you get the answer of 11, you found the answer!

STEP: Try putting brackets into the expression and see what happens
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

There is no way to solve this question following specific steps - you must try something and see what happens. (This is often called 'Guess & Check,' and it is a very useful strategy for solving unusual problems like this one.)

For example, you can try putting the brackets around the first two numbers, like this: (8÷10)+5−7(8÷10)+5−7. Then work it out and see if the answer comes out to be 11: if so, you have found the answer!

Shame, this guess did not work: it gives an answer of −1,2−1,2, not 11. That means one thing: you need to move the brackets to new places (take a new guess) and see what happens then!

In the end, the brackets must be in the positions shown here: 8÷(10+5−7)=18÷(10+5−7)=1. The following work shows that this must be correct:

The final answer is: 8 / (10 + 5 - 7) = 1.

Practice with the order of operations

Without using your calculator, evaluate the following expression:

−8+[1×9]−(−3)−8+[1×9]−(−3)

Note: If you use your calculator, you will not learn how to use BOEDMAS.

Answer: −8+[1×9]−(−3)−8+[1×9]−(−3) =
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The first letter in BOEDMAS is "B", so you should evaluate everything inside the brackets before you move to the operations outside them. In this question, the brackets that you need to look at are the square ones, since there are no operations inside the round ones.

STEP: Do the operation inside the brackets
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

In this case, we need to start at the beginning of BOEDMAS with "B" for brackets. In this question, that means starting inside the square brackets, since there are no operations inside the round ones. We should do the multiplication inside the brackets.

STEP: Do the operations outside the brackets
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now that we have done everything inside the brackets, we can do the calculations outside them. We need to decide on the order of operations outside the brackets. Since the operations are addition and subtraction, we should work from left to right.

We need to be careful throughout our calculations that we are treating the negative numbers correctly. For example, when we multiply or divide a negative number and a positive number, we will get a negative number.

It is useful to organise our work into a nice funnel shape, to keep track of our steps as we do them. We can use the 9 that we got from our work above - we already know that it is the value which comes from inside the square brackets.

So the final answer is 4.

BOEDMAS: expressions with brackets & exponents

You need to write out the answer step by step on paper. Do not type this expression into your calculator!

Answer: The value of the expression is: .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

When we include exponents in the order of operations, it becomes BOEDMAS. Operations in brackets always come first, followed by exponents (if there are any). There are brackets in this expression, so focus on the expression inside the brackets first, and ignore everything else until you finish the operations inside the brackets.

STEP: <no title>
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

To find the answer, you need to follow the four steps of BO-E-DM-AS. This expression has brackets in it, so your eyes should go straight to the business inside the brackets: (13×13)(13×13).

Notice that there are two calculations to do inside of the brackets: the exponent and multiplication. You must do these in the order that you follow for 'DM-AS' as usual, exactly as if you were evaluating 13×1313×13 all by itself.

Your working should look like this. The steps are highlighted with the blue underline and arrow.

The solution should be arranged like the work above: let the numbers come down, inside of a funnel shape. It is very important to organise your work like this: it will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct answer is 33.

BOEDMAS: expressions with integers

Solve this question by writing out your answer, step by step, on paper - do not type it into a calculator, or you won't learn how to use BOEDMAS!

Evaluate:

9−11+(−8)9−11+(−8).

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
There are brackets in this expression. However, these brackets do not have any operations inside: they are just holding the "−8−8" to make the negative more obvious. Therefore, there is nothing to do for the 'BO' step in BO-E-DM-AS. What is the first operation you find from E-DM-AS?
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BOEDMAS. To summarize, here is what BOEDMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "E" ⟶⟶ do any exponents; exponents always come before multiplication and division!
  3. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in four pieces: BO-E-DM-AS.

NOTE: There are brackets in this expression, but there are no operations inside of the brackets, only a single number. The 'BO' part of BOEDMAS tells us to start with the operations inside of brackets... in this expression there are no operations inside of brackets!

In this expression there are two operations: subtraction and addition. Which one does BO-E-DM-AS say to do first? The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right. Make sure you organise your work in a nice funnel shape, as shown below.

When we get to the second calculation, we need to simplify the signs in the expression: the calculation includes adding a negative number, which becomes subtraction.

The correct final answer is −10−10.

NOTE: Notice that this solution includes a step where addition changes into subtraction: this is the reason why we must do addition and subtraction from left to right - if they can mix like this, we must treat that as equals!

9×3◻9=39×3◻9=3

Answer: The missing operation is: .

For the first guess, we will try multiplication. You might pick a different first guess - no problem!

With the guess of multiplication the expression changes as follows: 9×3◻9⟶9×3×99×3◻9⟶9×3×9. Working out this expression, you get 243243. What does this mean? It means that ×× is the wrong guess, because the original equation shows that the answer is supposed to be 33, not 243243.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The correct choice for the operation in the ◻◻ is division. The proof that this works out is the calculation:

We can see that 9×3÷9=39×3÷9=3, just like it is supposed to be! Therefore, the correct final answer is ÷÷.

BODMAS: the order of operations including brackets

Complete this question without using a calculator. You should write down your working first, and then type in your final answer.

Evaluate the following expression:

5×(6÷3)5×(6÷3).

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: 5×(6÷3)5×(6÷3). This expression includes division and multiplication, but it also includes brackets! We always do the operations inside brackets before operations outside of the brackets! In this case that means we must start with division, and the multiplication must wait.

It is a common mistake to think that division must always come before multiplication because BO-DM-AS makes it look like that. However, that is not correct! Division and multiplication are so similar (like they are backward from each other) that they have equal 'strength:' one is not stronger than the other.

The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right.

The calculation in brackets is highlighted in blue in the work below. After we finish the calculations in the brackets, we can leave the brackets off!

It is important for you to organise your working like the example above. Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. Keeping your work organised like this will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 1010.

BODMAS: the order of operations including brackets

Complete this question without using a calculator. You should write down your working first, and then type in your final answer.

Find the value of this expression:

(15÷15)×7(15÷15)×7.

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: (15÷15)×7(15÷15)×7. This expression includes division and multiplication, but it also includes brackets! We always do the operations inside brackets before operations outside of the brackets! In this case that means we must start with division, and the multiplication must wait.

It is a common mistake to think that division must always come before multiplication because BO-DM-AS makes it look like that. However, that is not correct! Division and multiplication are so similar (like they are backward from each other) that they have equal 'strength:' one is not stronger than the other.

The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right.

The calculation in brackets is highlighted in blue in the work below. After we finish the calculations in the brackets, we can leave the brackets off!

It is important for you to organise your working like the example above. Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. Keeping your work organised like this will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 77.

In this question, that means starting inside the square brackets, since there are no operations inside the round ones. We need to decide on the order of operations inside the brackets. Since the operations are subtraction and multiplication, we should start with the multiplication, and then do the subtraction.

STEP: Do the operation outside the brackets

BOEDMAS: expressions with integers

Solve this question by writing out your answer, step by step, on paper - do not type it into a calculator, or you won't learn how to use BOEDMAS!

Evaluate the following expression:

(−11)+8−12(−11)+8−12.

Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
There are brackets in this expression. However, these brackets do not have any operations inside: they are just holding the "−11−11" to make the negative more obvious. Therefore, there is nothing to do for the 'BO' step in BO-E-DM-AS. What is the first operation you find from E-DM-AS?
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you evaluate an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BOEDMAS. To summarize, here is what BOEDMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "E" ⟶⟶ do any exponents; exponents always come before multiplication and division!
  3. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  4. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in four pieces: BO-E-DM-AS.

NOTE: There are brackets in this expression, but there are no operations inside of the brackets, only a single number. The 'BO' part of BOEDMAS tells us to start with the operations inside of brackets... in this expression there are no operations inside of brackets!

In this expression there are two operations: addition and subtraction. Which one does BO-E-DM-AS say to do first? The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right. Make sure you organise your work in a nice funnel shape, as shown below.

The correct final answer is −15−15.

BODMAS: the order of operations

Evaluate:

2+8−52+8−5

Answer: 2+8−5=2+8−5=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You should think of BODMAS in three parts: BO-DM-AS. There are no brackets in this question, so start with any division or multiplication that you see. If you see them both, you must do them left to right, like when reading a sentence. After you do all of the division and multiplication, then you should do all of the addition and subtraction; these also should be done from left to right.

STEP: Follow the order of operations
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever you work out an expression, you must follow the order of operations, BODMAS. To summarize, here is what BODMAS tells us to do:

  1. "BO" ⟶⟶ do all operations inside of brackets first; leave the operations outside of the brackets until later
  2. "DM" ⟶⟶ do division and multiplication from left to right; division does not always come before multiplication!
  3. "AS" ⟶⟶ do addition and subtraction from left to right; addition does not always come before subtraction!

Therefore, it is helpful to think of the order of operations in three pieces: BO-DM-AS.

We must use BO-DM-AS to evaluate this expression: 2+8−52+8−5.

This question includes addition and subtraction. Many people think that you must always add before you subtract because BO-DM-AS makes it look that way. However, addition and subtraction have equal 'strength:' one of them is not stronger than the other!

The correct way to do this calculation is to start with the operation on the left first, and then move to the right.

The first calculation we need to do is addition because it is on the left; then we will do the subtraction after that. (This step is highlighted with the blue underline and arrow.) Your working should be organised like this:

Notice how the working comes down, in the shape of a funnel. It is very important to organise your work like this: it will help you avoid mistakes!

The correct final answer is 55.

If he gets R10 688,00R10 688,00 at the end of the period, what effective interest rate did the bank offer him? Give answer correct to one decimal place.

Answer: The interest rate is % per annum.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

  • P=6 400,00P=6 400,00
  • i=?i=?
  • n=11n=11
STEP: Transform the compound interest formula for ii
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

This question is about a compound interest situation, so we need to use the compound interest formula. To calculate the interest rate, we can make ii the subject of the formula:

AAP(AP)1n(AP)1n−1=P(1+i)n=(1+i)n=1+i=iA=P(1+i)nAP=(1+i)n(AP)1n=1+i(AP)1n−1=i
STEP: Substitute the values and evaluate the answer

For the situation in this question, the effective interest rate is 4,8%4,8% per annum.

Population growth

The current population of Johannesburg is 3 877 2503 877 250 and the average rate of population growth in South Africa is 0,7%0,7% p.a.

What can city planners expect the population of Johannesburg to be in 1313 years time?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the nearest integer.
Answer: The city planners can expect the population to be .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Population growth follows a compound growth pattern. You can start by writing down the compound interest formula. Then you need to figure out what values to substitute into the formula.

STEP: Organise the information from the question
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

Read the question carefully and write down the given information. The population given in the question is like a starting amount in a bank account. The population growth rate is like an interest rate for the account.

  • A=?A=?
  • P=3 877 250P=3 877 250
  • i=0,7100i=0,7100
  • n=13n=13
STEP: Use the compound interest formula
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Populations grow following a compounding pattern, so we must use the compound interest formula. Substitute the values above into the formula.

A=P(1+i)n=3 877 250(1+0,7100)13=3 877 250(1,007)13=4 245 285,690...=4 245 286A=P(1+i)n=3 877 250(1+0,7100)13=3 877 250(1,007)13=4 245 285,690...=4 245 286
NOTE: The answer needs to be rounded to the nearest integer, since you cannot have a fraction of a person!

In 1313 years the population of Johannesburg is expected to be 4 245 2864 245 286.
